Activity: Boot up the workstation, grab a coffee, and check emails. Briefly scan industry news for any cool new 3D modeling techniques or software updates.

Review the character designs provided by @cart-1 (Concept Artist). Make sure I have a solid understanding of the characters' overall look, proportions, and key features. Create a folder structure to organize character model assets.

Start blocking out the base mesh for the first main character in Maya. Focus on establishing accurate proportions and a solid anatomical foundation. I'll use simple shapes like spheres and cylinders initially.
Refine the character's silhouette and primary forms. I'll pay close attention to landmarks and muscle groups to ensure the base mesh looks believable, even at this early stage.
Lunch Break. Grab some food with colleagues, maybe play some quick rounds of a game to unwind.
Continue refining the character blockout, paying specific attention to the face and hands. Add basic facial feature placeholders.
Take a break. Browse ArtStation for character model inspiration and new techniques. I'll save any particularly good examples for later reference.
Finalize the character blockout and export it as an FBX file. Save the Maya scene and document the progress with a brief summary of the day's work.
Respond to any emails, check the project management tool for any updates or new tasks, and prepare for tomorrow's focus on environmental models.
